citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility did not identify a dog (Male, fawn, Pug #7343) to have a medical issue prior to today's inspection. The dog has
been at the facility since October 2023. The dog's left eye is smaller than normal and has an abnormally placed pupil
(directed down and toward the left). The bottom eyelid is also rolled inward toward the eyeball. This condition can occur at
birth as a congenital abnormality, or long after an injury (scarring), and may result in abnormal vision. The licensee has
not noticed this issue prior to today's inspection. Failure to identify medical issues can result in delayed diagnostics and
treatment. Daily observation must be performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being, with any
abnormalities being noted on the medical record. Correct by ensuring daily observations on all dogs are thorough, and
furthermore, that direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian is performed so that timely and
accurate information on problems of animal health can be conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Medical issues noted
during daily observations need to be discussed with the attending veterinarian, their instructions must be followed, and an
appropriate medical record needs to be created.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 24, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility did not identify a dog (Male, fawn, Pug #7343) to have a medical issue prior to today's inspection. The dog has 
been at the facility since October 2023. The dog's left eye is smaller than normal and has an abnormally placed pupil 
(directed down and toward the left). The bottom eyelid is also rolled inward toward the eyeball. This condition can occur at 
birth as a congenital abnormality, or long after an injury (scarring), and may result in abnormal vision. The licensee has 
not noticed this issue prior to today's inspection. Failure to identify medical issues can result in delayed diagnostics and 
treatment. Daily observation must be performed on all animals to assess their health and well-being, with any 
abnormalities being noted on the medical record. Correct by ensuring daily observations on all dogs are thorough, and 
furthermore, that direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian is performed so that timely and 
accurate information on problems of animal health can be conveyed to the attending veterinarian. Medical issues noted 
during daily observations need to be discussed with the attending veterinarian, their instructions must be followed, and an 
appropriate medical record needs to be created. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 24, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
